div.head: CHAPTER XV.
div.p: THE CAPTIVE OFFICERS.â€”THE HINDOO SACRIFICE.

THE indignation of the Sergeant at the horrid rites he saw in progress at the Hindoo temple, would have prompted him to rush in, sword in hand, if he had not been restrained by his Captain, who placed his hand on his arm, whispering in his ear, "Be quiet, my good fellow. We have not seen all yet, or I am much mistaken!"

There was now a pause of a few moments' duration, only broken by the hissing of the serpent, which, although the Brahmin had ceased his strange monotonous tune on the reed flute, still swayed its head to and fro to the same measure, as if it still proceeded. Then both the Brahmins spoke at once in a sort of recitative chorus, and although Captain Hawkins strained his sense of hearing to listen, and was a good Hindostanee scholar, he could not make out what they said. A scene, however, soon presented itself, which needed no words to enable the Captain fully to comprehend it.

At a sign from one of the priests of the idol, the Hindoo who was nearest to the archway that opened to the free air, withdrew with a howling reverence to the idol; and then the slow beat of a tom-tom or native drum, was heard, and some half-dozen Sepoys, wearing some portion of the uniform of one of the revolted regiments, made their appearance, surrounding several ferocious-looking natives, who appeared to be dragging along with them some long bundle or package, tied up in cloth, and bound round by a rope.

The curiosity of the Captain was wound up to the highest pitch to know what this could all mean; but he was not kept long in suspense. At an order from one of the Brahmins, the strange-looking parcel was unrolled and dragged out of the coverings. Apparently more dead than alive, for she could not stand, appeared a young girl, certainly of not more than fourteen years of age; and although her apparel was torn and disordered, the Captain recognised it as that worn by the females of the Mahomedan races of India.

She tried to stand, but was evidently too weak; and she sunk to the floor, uttering piteous cries, but in a low weak voice, as though she were either half-starved, or had been subject to ill-usage sufficient to deprive her of all strength.

"Wretch!" said one of the Brahmins; "wretch, of an accursed race who deny the ancient gods of India, your time has come! Your blood shall be an acceptable offering; and all who touch it, or see it flow, shall be more sacred than the brothers of Siva, and shall prevail over the Feringhee!"
"Mercy!--oh, mercy!" sighed the girl.
"We do not know the word!" said the Brahmin, with an impatient gesture. "You die the death! You it was who gave information to the Feringhee post, at Goerka, and you die the death!"
"Oh, no!--no! In mercy spare me! My kindred are rich! They will heap gold upon your shrine! Oh, holy prophet! I am young to die! Mercy! have mercy upon me!"
"Sergeant?" whispered Captain Hawkins, hoarsely.
"Yes, your honour!"
"Run back the way we came, and bring three or four of your men with you. Quick,--on your life!"
The Sergeant did not reply to a single word, but darted off, first on his hands and knees, and then, springing to his feet, he flew, rather than ran, down the passage to the great hall.
"Guard the entrance securely," said one of the priests.
The Sepoys, with ferocious pleasure, fixed their bayonets, and stood ready to resist all comers.
"Now, brother!" added the Brahmin to the other, who, gravely nodding his head, brought forth a small bag from behind the idol, from which he took a broad-bladed knife.
The Mahomedan girl utttered shriek upon shriek!
A ferocious Sepoy darted forward, and twined his large hand in her fair hair, and tried to force her head back, so as to expose her neck to the Brahmin with the knife!

Captain Hawkins could bear no more! Had he felt that he must be alone through all the fearful struggle that must ensue, he would have plunged into the midst of them to save that sweet, delicate young girl from such a death!
"Hold!" he cried, with a voice that echoed through the place and seemed to paralyze every one in the unhallowed temple. "Hold! incarnate fiends!"

His revolver was in his hand, and the first bullet from it hit the ruffian who held the young girl by the hair, and sunk deep into his brain. The feelings of the young officer were too much excited to permit him to stay where he was and fire at the miscreant throng; but, thrusting his revolver back into its belt, he vaulted over the rocky breastwork in front of him; and, sword in hand, rushed at the Brahmin with the knife.

The Brahmin was a tall and powerful man, and he made a lounge at the heart of the young offier which, but that his thick buff pistol-belt turned the point aside, would have terminated his career at once.
"Death to the Feringhee!" shrieked the priest.
That was his last shriek, for the sword of the Captain cleft him to the very eyes!

The Sepoys, however, seeing that there was but one man, made a rush towards him as soon as they recovered from the first shock of their amazement; but, as they were upon the point of reaching him, Captain Hawkins heard a loud shout from the Sergeant, who cried to him, "Stoop, your honour!--stoop, your honour, till we give them a volley!"
Captain Hawkins understood the Sergeant's tactics in a moment; and, clasping the young Mahomedan girl in his arms, he flung himself on the floor with her.
"Fire!" cried the Sergeant.
A volley of musketry, on the instant, resounded through the place.
The cries of the Sepoys, and the curses of the Brahmin, sounded through the smoke, and mingled with the ring of the ramrods of the soldiers as they reloaded.
"Fire!" again cried the Sergeant; and another volley rung through the temple.

"Forward, my boys!" then shouted the Sergeant; and as the Captain sprung to his feet, and lifted the young girl in his arms, he found himself surrounded by the soldiers, and that the victory was won. Some half-dozen of the Sepoy guard lay on the floor with the dead Brahmin; but the other priest of the hideous temple was nowhere to be seen..
"A guard to the door!" shouted the Captain. "A couple of men, Sergeant! Shoot, or bayonet, whoever attempts to pass!"
"All right, your honour!"
"Look behind the idol! I saw some one go that way!"

The Sergeant darted in the direction pointed out by his officer; and, in a moment, dragged out the other priest, who had flown there for shelter from the bullets: he made a desperate attempt to escape, but a couple of soldiers bound his hands behind him with their belts.
There was a flush upon the face of Captain Hawkins now, as he cried, "Take him out! Take him outside!"
"Yes, your honour! And--and--"
"Shoot him!"
"Yes, your honour!"
The Brahmin uttered a howl as he was dragged into the open air. The report of a couple of muskets in another moment echoed through the neighbouring wood, and the Sergeant returned.
"That's done, your honour! Is the poor young thing dead?"
"No, no!"
"Why, she is but a child, sir! What bloodthirsty ruffians!"
"Bloodthirsty, indeed! Post a sentinel here, Sergeant! I will take this poor young creature, who seems to have fainted, to the ladies: they will understand what to do with her better than I shall!"

In the excitement of the moment, Captain Hawkins never felt the slight weight of the young Mahomedan girl, but vaulted with her over the rocky breastwork; and hurring down the passage, he appeared in the great hall of the rock temple, saying, "Ladies, here is a present for you!"

The alarm of the party in the rock temple at the firing and sound of conflict so close to them, had been great; and now that the Captain, with all the hurry of the recent tumult in hsi manner, burst in upon them, with what looked certainly more like a dead body than anything else, Miss Flint uttered a scream, and there was a general agitation among them all.
"Don't be alarmed!" added the Captain. "It is only a young Mahomedan girl that I have rescued from the Brahmins!"
"Don't bring the creature here!" cried Miss Flint. "I daresay she is no better than she should be!"
"But if she is as good, my dear madam," said Captain Hawkins, "I think that will be sufficient; and, at all events, if she is as good as she is beautiful, she is good indeed!"

As he spoke, the young officer laid the still form of the young creature on the floor, of the temple; and when Bessie Hope saw the pale face, and the delicately beautiful features, so pale and wan, as though death had indeed set up his sole dominion there, she rushed forward, exclaiming, "And they have killed her?"
"I trust not, Miss Hope! I don't think they had a chance to do that. My impression is that she has fainted!"
"Water!--water!" cried Bessie. "Oh, mother, help her--help her! She is not one of us, by creed or by country, but she is helpless and in need of aid, and then the whole human race are kin!"
"By Jove," said Caesar, "if that girl Bessie Hope is not a trump, Adrian!"
"She is," said Adrian--"she is all that--that--"
"Why, hilloa! what a colour you have all of a sudden!" added Caesar, as the young Lieutenant flushed with pleasure to hear her whom he loved praised.
By this time, however, all question as to whether the young Mussulman girl was dead or alive was set at rest, by her opening a pair of the loveliest eyes in the world, and looking timidly about her.
"Be not alarmed," said Bessie, "you are safe now."

Tears gushed to the eyes of the young girl; and as she happened to see Captain Hawkins, she sprung from the stone floor of the temple, and from Bessie's lap, on which her fair head was lying, and flinging her arms round the Captain's neck, she cried, "My friend! my preserver! Oh, how shall I thank and bless you ever and ever?"

"Don't think of it," said Captain Hawkins, who felt rather embarrassed at the hasty character of the embrace. "Don't think of it, at all. I am only too happy to have been the means of saving you from the Brahmin who would have made a sacrifice of you."

"Well I am sure," said the Hon. Miss Flint, as she procured from some hidden recess of a pocket, a large fan, and placed it open before her eyes. "I never did see such bold, shameless conduct! To be hugging a he creature like that, and before everybody, too! This is Indian manners and morals, I suppose?"
"She is a child of nature, my dear Miss Flint," said Caesar.
"A child of a fiddlestick, sir," said Miss Flint, with an indignant toss of the head. "If she were twenty children of nature, she should behave with propriety."
The Captain gently disengaged the arms fo the young Mahomedan girl from about him, as he said, "And what is your name, my dear?"
"Zeelook. Ah, they are all killed! Father--mother--all! I am alone, with no one in all the world to love me now, but you!"
"Really," cried Miss Flint, "this is abominable! Ladies, are you going to sit still and hear such things!"

The others smiled slightly, and Bessie Hope gently led the girl to the midst of the little party, and she said, "We will all love you, if you will share our fortune with us. We are but fugitives ourselves; but such protection as we can give you, shall be yours freely."

The young creature hurriedly embraced and kissed Bessie on the cheek, but it was plain that she had eyes and ears for little else but Captain Hawkins. They gave her refreshment, for she was half-famished; then, in answer to their inquiries, she said in a soft, lute-like voice, "Oh, we were too happy, when this dreadful war broke outl and the English officers had been kind to my poor father, when the Brahmins sought his life; so I went to warn them that the bad men were consulting over their destruction, and when I returned my home was a pyramid of fire, and my kindred murdered. The Sepoys seized me, and brought me to the odious temple, where Allah is unknown, and the Prophet a scoff. You rescued me, dear one!"
Again she flew to the side of the Captain, and clasping both her arms round one of his, she laid her head gently upon his shoulder, with a sigh of joy!
"Creature! hussey!" cried Miss Flint. "How dare you? I wonder at such unblushing conduct! Of course, you guess he is a single man, and think you will get settled?"
A peal of laughter from the whole party, which they could not resist, followed this speech, and the Mahomedan girl shrink back, saying faintly, "Ah, what have I done?"
"Nothing! my dear, good Zeelook," said Captain Hawkins. "Nothing at all!"
"Ah, yes! I am unveiled before men!"

"Never mind that. You see that the English ladies do not veil; so cast aside that notion, and remain with them. Can you tell me the name of the station at which you warned the English officers of the approach of the Sepoys?"
"Oh, yes, love. It is called Audab."
"Ah! That is on the road to Agra. If there is a force there, we cannot do better than to try to join it."
"Captain Hannibal Hawkins!" cried Miss Flint.
"Madam!"
"Weill you explain to your heathen, if you please, that dear and ove are not fit expressions to be used to single men!"
"Don't you do any such thing, Hannibal," laughed Caesar. "I only wish she would call me such names. My ears tingle to hear them from her pretty lips!"
"Sir!" added Miss Flint; "please to increase your distance from me!"
"With pleasure, madam."

"Nay, nay," said Captain Hawkins; "don't let us quarrel about the artless expressions of gratitude of this young girl. She associates no shadow of harm by such ters, and we must not judge her by our own old European fashions. I would not check her for the world."
"Nor I!" said Bessie Hope, kissing her.
"Nor I!" said Mrs. Fletcher.
Even Mrs. Hope joined in the general exculpation of the poor Mahomedan girl; and only Mrs. Hawkins looked a little doubtful on the subject.

More important matters, however, than the settlement of points of female etiquette now called for the attention of the party. The day was sinking, and a dim twilight was gathering in the valleys, so that if they did not intend--which assuredly they did not--to take up their quarters for the night in the rock temple, it was time to think of moving.

A couple of the soldiers, with the Sergeant, were sent out as scouts, to reconnoitre the route from the entrance to the temple and they reported that all was still, only in one quarter of the sky, over the tree-tops, they thought there was a strange reddish light which was not altogether natural.

"It is likely enough some conflagration," said the Captain, as he stepped to the open space in front of the temple. From thence he himself saw the strange aspect of the heavens in the quarter that had attracted the attention of the Serjeant; and as even in the few moments that he looke dat it the intensity of the red glare altered several times, he no longer had any doubt but that it was a large fire of some sort.

"It is now time to march," he said, as he returned to the inner part of the temple. "Let us hope that we shall soon find some means of enabling you all to ride, ladies; but at present we ave no resource but to go on foot."

They all cheerfully rose, and prepared for a night march in the direction of Cawnpore, to which they still directed their hopes, in the full belief that there was a sufficiently strong British force there to hold the place. In a few minutes they all quitted the rock temple, which had been to them a most welcome place of shelter, and commenced the march

The Captain went forward himself, with two of the soldiers as a sort of advanced guard, and the main body of the party, with the exception of a rear-guard of two others of the soldiers, and the Corporal, followed at about a hundred and fifty paces distant.

The cessation of what may be properly called daylight is quick in India, and by the time they had reached a quarter of a mile from the rock temple the large lustrous stars shone out sweetly from the deep blue sky. The moon would not rise until late, so that the night was about as dark as itwould be in that fair clime, and the banian trees, of which they met and passed several groups, sent dark shadows across their path. A soft delicious stillness was in the air, and the silence was only broken by the drowsy hum of some of the insect tribe, whose habits are altogether nocturnal.
Once only, in the distance, they heard th ecry of a jackall, and then some large bird of prey passed over the heads of the party, flapping its long heavy wings in the night air.

Captain Hawkins had, in addition to the watchfulness which was necessary to be kept up, for fear of rousing some enemy, to be continally peering about him to make sure that he was on the right path. Once before--but it was some years ago--he had ridden from Delhi to Cawnpore, and he thought he should be able to track the way again with certainty, but still he had a doubt if he were quite right or not, more than once or twice.

"Halt!" he said, suddenly; "we are close to a village here, which I recollect; and we ought to pass through it, although whether it will be prudent or not I can scarcely say. Caesar! Caesar! Come here!"
"What is it?"
"Do you know the village close to here?"

Caesar glanced about him, and then replied, "To be sure I do. I know it now. We must march through it, for if we don't, we shall deviate into some low marshy ground, which, on drained strips, is planted with rice; and if once we get into the water channels and rice-fields we may wander about for hours."
"Then you think we should push on?"
"Oh, yes; at once."
"Forward, then!--I still lead the way. We may pass through the village unobserved. Advise silence on all."
This was done; and, in addition to the silence of the party, they trod as lightly as they could, and were soon among the wretched huts of which the village was composed.

Notwithstanding all their caution--though it was impossible that a party of such numbers could pass through the village without some little noise--as they expected, a door suddenly opened, and a man as suddenly appeared at it, with a torch of resinous wood in his hand, which at once sent a bright, flickering glare upon the whole party.
"Quick, march!" cried the Captain. "Get clear of the houses as soon as you all can!"

They all quickened their steps, and then a bright flare of light suddenly shot from a heap of dry grass, which had evidently been set light to that it might serve as a kind of beacon. A shout of some fify or sixty voices rung through the air; and just as the Captain, who had flown to the rear, got his party past the last hovel in the village, shots began to be fired in rapid succession.

Whether this was merely an attack for the sake of plunder on the part of the villagers, or they had any of the revolted Sepoys at hand, was a point on which Captain Hawkins felt some anxiety, but which at the moment he had no means of deciding. He, therefore, still pushed on, till getting clear of the village, he came upon a number of logs of trees, lying across the roadway in such a fashion, that it would have been quite out of the question for any carriage to have effected a passage; and, indeed, good horsement could hardly have picked their way through the intricacies of the obstruction.

That these newly felled trees were there placed for the express purpose of obstructing the flight of fugitives in vehicles, there could be little or no doubtl but the Captain, with a military eye, saw at once, that if they were an obstruction in one respect, they formed a good defence in another.

"Halt!" he cried, as he brought his party to the logs. "We won't be huned a mile or two by the rabble of a village! Here, my men, just place some of these lighter trunk of trees upon the other! That will do! Now, where is the enemy?"
So admirable was the disposition of the Captain, that in a very few minutes, by the aid of the logs, he was pretty fairly and securely intrenched.

The villagers, with torches, came yelling on; and when they got near to the logs, they fired several muskets at the fugitives. A ball slightly touched the Sergeant, who said, "Shall we give them a volley, sir!"
"Wait a moment! The road narrows hereabouts! They will be closer directly!"

Scarcely anticipating resistance from so small a party, the villagers, to the number of about a hundred, came rushing on in a wild disorderly throng, brandishing knives and tulwars; while those who had muskets loaded and fired as quickly as they could.
"Now," said the Captain--"all ready?"
"Ready, sir!" said the Sergeant.
"Aim low, my men! Fire!"

The volley fell into the very thick of the rabble rout, and every bullet told once, if not twice. Roaring cries of pain arose, and the torches were flung aside, and a general retreat ensued, which, in a few moments, left not a living enemy upon the field. Some dark
objects lying in the roadway, though, sufficiently testified to the fact that the volley had not been without its effect.
"That will do," said the Captain. "They will not attack us again! They have had enough of us! Let us resume our march!"
"Hold!" said Lieutenant Adrian. "I hear the tramp of horses' feet! Ah! who, and what, is that?"

A single horseman galloped up to within twenty feet of the logs of trees by which the road was barred, and dim as the night light was, there was no mistaking the fact of his being a Sepoy cavalry man. His accoutrements glittered faintly, and they could see that his drawn sword was in his hand.
"Ho, Sahibs!" he cried. "Whither fly you from friends?"
"What regiment?" said Captain Hawkins, sternly.

"That!" repied the Sepoy soldier; and having, unobserved by the party behind the trees, possessed himself of both of his holster-pistols, one in each hand, he fired them right at the head of the Captain; and them, by the pressure of his knees, wheeling round his horse, while he lay quite flat on his back, he was off at a gallop before any one could find time to act against him.
"That's some close touch," said Captain Hawkins, as he dabbed up some blood from his cheek, in which a bullet had made a furrow about skin deep.
"Are you hit, Hannibal?" said Caesar.
"Well I hardly know yet, but I think it's all right! Hang the fellow, he did it cleverly enough!"
"Cavalry! cavalry!" cried Lieutenant Adrian. "They are upon us!"
"Not yet, I think!" shouted the Captain.

With a tramp that shook the ground, a troop of revolted cavalry, probably on their route from some out-station to Delhi, charged up to the logs, no dount thinking them a trifling obstruction, and that they would soon sabre the small English party.

"Fire!" cried the Captain again ; and the volley checked the horsemen in full career, with the exception of three, who leaped over the logs. One, a gigantic Sepoy, made a ferocious cut at Captain Hawkins, whcih with difficulty he parried, but in doing so his foot caught in a projecting branch from one of the trees, and he stumbled to his knees.

Again the Sepoy raised his sword and uttered a wild shout of triumph, when a shot came right over the shoulders of the Captain as he was struggling to rise, and, hitting the savage in the face, hurled him from his horse.

The other two cavalry men were quickly disposed of by the soldiers, and the three horses were seized at once, as spoils of war. The Captain struggled now to his feet, half stunned by the blow that the Sepoy's sword had given him as it beat down his guard; and he called out, "Who fired that shot? Who killed the fellow!"
"Ah, I was near you!" said the Mahomedan girl, as she crouched at his feet with his own revolver in her hand, which he recollected he had placed close behind him on one of the fallen trees.
"And you saved me?"
"I am happy!" she replied, as the tears flowed from her eyes. "They tell me I must not say I love you--that I must not embrace you--but I can defend you!"
"My dear Zeelook, I love you, though, and all the world and all the old maids in it shall not prevent me from saying so, and embracing you!"

As he spoke, he caught the young girl in his arms and kissed her cheek. She trembled like a frightened bird; but before another word could be spoken, or Miss Flint could express her disapprobation of the Captain's conduct, the Sergeant called out, "We must evacuate the position, your honour. Look what they are at now!"

The Captain did look, and a pang of dismay came across his heart as he now saw the Sepoys dragging up a gun, which, although by its size probably only a nine-pounder, yet would, if efficiently served, soon play havoc with their little entrenchment.
"Heaven help us now!" said the Captain; "but we must be off! Cavalry and artillery! What are we to do?"

The Sepoys crowded round the gun with blazing torches and such shouts of exultation, that it was pretty clear what their opinion was of its efficacy. Close to the side of the wood was the little copse from which the trees had been cut to stop the road; and as the Captain glanced around him, he thought that there they would at least be better protected rom the horsemen. He caught the Sergeant by the arm, and whispered in hsi ear, "Sergeant, keep up a fire from these logs in ront, so as to shroad us a little with the smoke, and let your men take off their jackets and caps, and bestrew them about the logs and branches, so as to look, in the uncertain light, like men lying hidden."
"I understand, sir!"
The Captain flew to where the ladies were cowering down in alarm, and got them to display a few shalws and spare clothing upon the trunks of the felled trees.
The Sergeant and three men kept up a desultory fire on the Sepoys, assisted by Caesar and his father, until the Captain said, in a low but distinct voice, "Stoop low, all of you, and follow me!"
The firing cease, and stooping so low tha they could not be readily seen behind the breastwork of logs, they all passed, to the right, into the little wood.

It was at this moment that the Sepoys, who were but amateur gunners, fired their first round shot, and it fell crashing amidst the logs. They then tired to get up a cheer, and by the flame of their torches they still fancied they saw the party of English soldiers and fugitives crouching down amid the logs. Again and again they loaded and fired, but the stillness and the silence among the logs alarmed the so much that they hesitated to advance, and the cavalry men manifestly hung back, fully anticipating a warm reception if they ventured on another charge.

div.head: CHAPTER XVI.
div.p: THE SISTERS AND ZEELOOK.â€”THE STREAM AND THE ESCAPE.

TREADING almost in each others' footsteps, and preserving a complete silence, the party who had so adroitly left the little entrenchment of logs followed Captain Hawkins through the wood. As they went, they heard the cannonade going on at their abandoned position; and at times, no, as they got further and further out of the hearing of the Sepoys, a smothered laugh would come from one of the soldiers at the thought of the successful ruse that had been played upon their foes.

By the time the gun had been fired about a dozen times, our friends were nearly half a mile from the spot, and they found the wood suddenly closed, and that they were close to the banks of a little stream which wound its way lazily between one high bank and one low one--the low one, which was nearly laved by the water, being the opposite to that on which they stood.
With no small difficulty they had succeeded in bringing the cavalry horses with them, although one of them was badly wounded, and bled much as they led him along.
On emerhing from the trees, the night sky appeared to be wonderfuly bright, and they guessed that the moon was near to its rising.
"Now, brother, where are we?" said the Captain; "for I must confess that I am out of my latitude."
"And I," said Caesar.
There was a pause of irresolution; and then the Mahomedan girl was brought forward by Bessie Hope, as she said, Zeelook knows the place well, she says, and can guide us."
"That is providential!" exclaimed the Captain.
"Yes," said the girl. "The stream is named the Jeed, and it runs through a valley here at hand, and then across the high road to Agra again.
"That will do, my dear Zeelook!" said the Captain; "and now each of these troop-horses will easily carry two ladies, and that will do for six of you."
"I can walk," said Zeelook, as with a rapid glance around she saw that there were six ladies without her.
"Oh!" said Bessie, "we will take it by turns, dear Zeelook--that is, you and I. When you have ridden some way you will alight and I will ride."
"You first," said the girl, kissing Bessie's hand as she spoke.
"No, I am far from tired."

"Settle it among you," said the Captain, as he made as skilful preparations as he could for the comfort of the other ladies on the cavalry horses; and when all were mounted but Zeelook, and Bessie, and Miss Flint, the latter said, "No, sir! No, Captain Hannibal Hawkins, I do not choose to ride with unprincipled heathens! If Miss Hope rides, I will; but let the creature get down!"

The fact was that, at the moment Miss Flint began to speak, Bessie had prevailed upon Zeelook to ride first, and Captain Hawkins, making nothing at all of her light weight, had placed her on the horse.

"Miss Flint, he said, "I do not want to quarrel with a lady; but if you have any regard for me or my family, by whom you have been a well-respected guest, be so good as to speak a little more charitably of this young lady, to whom I owe my life!"
"Lady?" shrieked Miss Flint.
"Arrah, thin, ma'am," said an Irish soldier, "do you want to bring the niggers down on us by that hubaboo?"
"Sirm" said Miss Flint, "will you be soo good as to try by a court martial, or whatever you may call it, this insolent common soldier?"

"Hush, madam!--hush! Silence in the ranks! Nay, Zeelook, sit still! All is well! Miss Hope is not ashamed to ride with you, nor I to hold your bridle, and be your guard! Come, Miss Hope, since our friend Miss Flint chooses a longer march, allow me!"
The Captain lifted Bessie Hope to the saddle, and then Bessie said, "Miss Flint, I will alight as soon as you please to ride."

To this obliging offer Miss Flint only replied by an indignant toss of the head, and a jerk of her aristocratic nose, as if she were intent upon performing the juggling feat of which some sogs are so proud--namely, of jerking a piece of meat off the end of their noses, and then catching it in their mouths before it has time to gravitate to the earth.
"Now, in the name of heaven, let us go on!" said the Captain, "for the gun has ceased firing, and our enemies cannot be very far off!"

The road by the banks of the stream was broken and irregular, and the horses trod uneasily. The Captain, leading the horse on which was Bessie Hope and Zeelook, took the lead, and that which was ridden by Mrs. Fletcher and her mother followed immediately under the care and guidance of Lieutenant Adrian. Little did this party of sad and anxious fugitives suspect the catastrophe that was at hand.

They passed on till they suddenly turned the corner of the wood, through which they had passed, and then, to their surprise and horror, a blaze of light from blue-lights and torches flashed upon them, and a roar of voices broke upon their ears.

They were in the actual presence of some two thousand Sepoys, at the head of whom was some high native chief, or one of the royal family of Delhi, in a magnificent howdah, on the back of an elephant, the superb trappings of which swept the ground.

The Sepoy force and our little party of adventurers seemed to be for the moment equally surprised at the sight of each other; and there was a shout of gratification on one side and sighs of despair on the other.

"Lost! lost!" said the Captain, as he recoiled a step; and intuitively, rather than from any real expectation fo escaping, strove to back the horse he was leading into the wood again; but the other, so close behind it, resisted the movement, and all was confusion in the little cavalcade.

Screams burst from the lips of Mrs. Hawkins and Mrs. Hope, and Mrs. Fletcher, the latter of whom strove to jump from the horse, and fly with her little one for security into the wood, or anywhere that would take her from the gaze of the Sepoys.

The Sergeant, without waiting for orders, gave the world to his men to fire, which, in the face of such force, was useless, if not imprudent; for the rebellion was but at its beginning, and it was scarcely yet known what sort of treatment British prisoners might expect in the hands of the Sepoy princes, of which this man on the elephant seemed to be one of high rank.

The discharge of the soldiers' muskets into the thick of the Sepoy force, however, brought matters to a climax. Several guns were fired on the English party in teturn, and one shot struck Mr. Hawkins in the breast, and he fell with a deep groan. Another killed the Sergeant; and then, as if in obedience to an order from the leader on the elephant, the firing ceased, and a rush of some fifty Sepoys, armed with tulwars, was made at the little party. There was a clash of swords, shouts and cries for a few seconds; and of course the issue of such a contest could not be doubtful. All passed with the rapidity of a feverish dream, and Bessie Hope found herself still on the horse after it had taken a fearful leap in the middle of the stream that ran close at hand
It was the Mahomedan girl who held the bridle, and who urged the animal forward.
"On! on!" she cried. "Oh, do not speak! You may yet be saved! On! on! Hold fast for your life!"
"My sister! Oh, God, my sister and the child!" sobbed Jessie
"They follow!! All is well! Oh, no! no! He is lost, and I live! I cannot abandon him! Farewell!"
The young girl slipped from the saddle, and Bessie Hope heard a splash in the stream as she alighted in it.
"No! no!" cried Bessie. "Oh, stay with us! stay!"

It was too late, even if the exhortation had had a chance of being effectual. Zeelook was gone, but Bessie, as the horse she was on splashed through the stream, heard the snorting and rapid swimming of another close at hand to her. The fact was, that with the following or imitative power, which si so strongly developed in animals, the horse that was close to that ridden by Bessie and the young Mahomedan girl had leaped into the stream after its companion, but it only had one rider. Volumina Hawkins had, in the first terror of the attack of the Sepoy force, sprung screaming to the ground.
Bessie turned to see who it was that followed, and in the dim light she caught a glance at her sister, Mrs. Fletcher.
"Annie, Annie, is that you?"
"Yes! Oh, yes! I have saved my dear one!"
"Alas! Are we alone?"

"I know not! Bessie! Bessie! Do you hear those awful sounds! Oh, sister, let us pray, for surely our last hour has come! How can we, two helpless females, hope to escape alone through this fearful land?"
"Who shall say?" replied Bessie. "God is with us, and the life he has given to us we are bound to preserve as best we can! On, sister, on!"

The sounds that met the ears of the sisters were indeed fearful. There were cries and shrieks, and shouts of exultation, and the clash of weapons; and now and then the call of a bugle or the tap of a drum in the Sepoy ranks; and as all these sounds mingled strangely with each other as the sisters increased their distance from the scene of conflict, they felt their hearts sink within them, and even Bessie tried to turn her horse's head, and to stretch her arms in the direction of the spot they had left, as she cried, "No! no! I cannot bear this! It is too dreadful! Better, better far that we should perish together!"
"Oh, Bessie, what mean you?"
"Return! return! There seems something base in thus flying from those with whom we have gone through so many perils! Our mother, too! Oh, God, keep us and direct us now!"
"My child! My dear little one!" cried Mrs. Fletcher, as she burst into an agony of tears. "Oh, Bessie, let me hold this dear one to life and safety while I can!"
Bessie's tears ceased. She sighed deeply.
"You are right!" she said. "Annie, you are right! We have that young life to look to. On then~! on, in the name of heaven proceed, and let us yet do our best!"

Again, the horse's heads were turned away from that fatal wood, but now it became evident that the animals were getting exhausted with the swimming, and one, that on which Bessie rode, stumbled, and plunged completely over-head in the stream.
"To the bank, sister!" said Bessie. "Go to the right! The bank is low!"

The horses scrambled to the shore, and shook the water from their dripping manes. The moon at this moment rose from behind a clump of trees, and the sisters looked about them with a forlorn hope of being able to come to some conclusion as to where they were.

It was in vain that Mrs. Fletcher and Bessie Hope strained their eyes in all directions, aided by the beautiful moonlight, in order to discover the part of the country where they had landed with the horses from the stream. All was new and strange to them. There were trees~--there was the rippling water!--there were rocks piled up here and there in masses, and a quantity of low brushwood--from which arose, in the night air, the odour of sweet flowers--seemed to go far away to the illimitable darkness around, but there was no house, no hut, or evidences of human habitation. With a gush of tears, Bessie called aloud on the young Mahomedan girl by name; but a dismal echo only replied, and the sounds faded away in the fearful solitude around them!

"She is gone!--she is gone!" sobbed Bessie, "and we are alone in this fearful land! Oh, Annie, what will become of us now? All that we loved are lost to us; and she, who preserved us, has gone from us! She was not of our race, she was not of our creed, but her heart was human!"

Mrs. Fletcher seemed stupified, for a few moments, by despair: she could not strain her child to her breast, and seek to drain the water of the stream from its long fair curls. Bessie clasped her hand and stilled her sobs, for there was now come on the slight night-wind, the wild sounds of strife; and that strange light that the party had before observed on a particular part of the heavens, appeared to blaze out again with a fresh vigour. Then there was the loud sullen boom of a cannon which, in its reverberations, for a moment absorbed all other sounds.
The sisters clung to each other in silence. That sound seemed to forebode some catastrophe the nature of which they could not guess, but which on that very account appeared full of strange terror.
"Annie," said Bessie, "dear sister! It is still our duty to return, if we can, to those who are so near and dear to us! You have refused once--Oh, think again?"
"Kill me!--kill me!" said Mrs. Fletcher, "and then go! I cannot!--I have but one thought! It is here!--here!"
